casebody.data:
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee v. Joseph ROBICHEAUX, Defendant-Appellant. No. 12-30160

Summary Calendar.

United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Nov. 2, 2012. Cristina Walker, Assistant U.S. Attorney, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Shreveport, LA, for Plaintiff-Appellee. Joseph Robieheaux, Beaumont, TX, for Defendant-Appellant. Before JONES, DENNIS, and HAYNES, Circuit Judges. PER CURIAM: *

Joseph Robieheaux, federal prisoner # 70986-079, appeals the district court’s denial of a sentence reduction pursuant to *96618 U.S.C. § 3582(c)(2) based upon the amendment to the Guidelines that implemented the Fair Sentencing Act (FSA) of 2010. He argues that, even if his sentencing guidelines range was not lowered by the amendment, the district court can, after Kimbrough v. United States, 552 U.S. 85, 128 S.Ct. 558, 169 L.Ed.2d 481 (2007), reduce his sentence under § 3582(c)(2) based upon its consideration of the 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a) factors and his post-sentencing rehabilitative efforts. The district court’s ruling is reviewed for an abuse of discretion. United States v. Doublin, 572 F.3d 235, 237 (5th Cir.2009).

Under the Guidelines, as amended by the FSA, Robicheaux’s base offense level of 38 remained unchanged as he was held accountable for 35.6 kilograms of cocaine base, and, after the amendment, a base offense level of 38 applies to “8.4 KG or more of cocaine base.” See U.S.S.G. § 2Dl.l(c)(l). Robicheaux was thus ineligible for a sentence reduction because the amendment did not reduce his guidelines range. See § 3582(c)(2); U.S.S.G. § lB1.10(a)(2)(B). Moreover, the principles of United States v. Booker, 543 U.S. 220, 125 S.Ct. 738, 160 L.Ed.2d 621 (2005), and its progeny, including Kimbrough, do not apply to § 3582(c)(2) proceedings. See Dillon v. United States, — U.S. -, 130 S.Ct. 2683, 2691-94, 177 L.Ed.2d 271 (2010); Doublin, 572 F.3d at 238.

The Government’s motion for summary affirmance is GRANTED, and the judgment of the district court is AFFIRMED. The Government’s alternative motion for an extension of time in which to file a brief is DENIED as unnecessary.

Pursuant to 5th Cir. R. 47.5, the court has determined that this opinion should not be published and is not precedent except under the limited circumstances set forth in 5th Cir. R. 47.5.4.
